text: today and Applied Science we're going to
show you how I built these custom
electroluminescent displays these are
made from a pane of glass and the
segments are defined by screen printing
and then I have a high voltage driver to
make the electroluminescent display work
these happen to be a replica of the disc
II the dsk Y from the Apollo program so
this is what the astronauts use to
interact with the guidance computer in
the Apollo spacecraft part of the reason
I haven't uploaded a video in a while is
this has been one heck of a project
regular viewers will remember at the end
of last year I did a video on
electroluminescent displays and another
video on screen printing and those were
both in preparation to get to where we
are today so a huge multi segment screen
printed display with a pre complicated
electroluminescent driver to get all the
segments working and so you might be
asking well why go through all this
trouble you could just get a cell phone
and slip it in there and just program
the cell phone to display whatever we
want and that's totally true the purpose
of doing a project like this is to learn
new techniques use materials from the
period so when the Apollo program is
going there were no you know o LEDs or
LCDs or anything like that so using
materials of the time is cool and then
you know going through a whole bunch of
bugs squashing a bug that's consumed you
know 10 or 20 hours of your life is
pretty enjoyable in theory so in this
video I'm just going to describe the
most interesting bugs and how you can
get through this and another benefit of
me taking so long to get all this done
is that I've documented everything all
of it the firmware the board layout the
schematics the mechanical CAD the screen
printing graphics are all open-source
and on github so check out the link if
you're interested in this video I'm
going to talk about the mechanical
construction of this first then the
electronics and then the firmware last
and it's really the electronics that are
probably the most interesting part about
this this in fact was the most difficult
board bring up I've ever done in my
entire career for personal or work
projects and it was because of the high
voltages involved but not for the
reasons that you're probably thinking
like arcing was not a problem it was
much more devious than that so let's
let's take this apart so you can see how
it
all these gray pieces
he printed on the form - printer this is
gray Pro resin and I even printed the
threads in here and just have some
flathead screws holding this in and so
the the original form or the original
dimensions of this disc ii unit were
provided to me in a CAD document so i
actually transcribed all this into a
fusion 360 file and this part of it is
totally original to the cad document and
what i added was this little retainer
clip here so this comes apart like this
and you can see how this works the
retainer clip basically goes in like
this and then pinches that board inside
there so there's a little ledge in here
and the glass panel goes in there and
gets pinched in so pretty simple
mechanicals there and then you can see
that there's two boards to it and one of
the boards is bonded to the glass
display itself and then the other board
is the one that has the drivers and so
you know of course the first question is
why go through the trouble of two boards
and that comes down to the reason for
the interconnects like basically how do
we connect up to all the segments that
are screen-printed onto the glass which
we'll talk about in a second if we did
all the chips on everything on one board
we would need to do blind and buried
vias because the trick is that for the
interconnect layer we need to have
electrical segments on this side of the
board but we can't have any wiring
whatsoever on this side of the board or
those with light up to so basically the
requirement here is that only the
segment's are exposed copper on this
side and so you can have wiring on this
side and we can have chips here - but
routing the whole board without vias
obviously a via would go all the way
through I suppose you could use blind or
buried vias but that's a little bit more
advanced than this project calls for
there's a couple other benefits with
doing two boards like this - if we want
to use the same driver board and just
use a different display like a totally
different display it doesn't even have
to be a disk II it could be some other
custom cool alien dashboard or something
like that you can just use the same
driver board over and over and just plug
it into whatever display board you want
the connectors are these 60 pin board
the board connectors and I chose these
because they're relatively low density
since we're putting you know 320 volts
through here at most I didn't want the
pitch to be down to 0.4 0.5 millimeter I
believe these are point eight so we have
enough and I think the rating on these
actually is about three hundred and
somethin volts so it's we're actually
within spec which is how he's nice and
nothing to fancy it's just the
connectors that basically hold all this
together and I've actually had pretty
good luck with these connectors they're
pretty robust they provide enough
mechanical support so that the boards
you know you don't really need much more
than these let's talk about the display
glass itself I guess this is kind of one
of the most interesting parts of the
project or certainly the most unusual
part that I've basically had this part
working for a long time and have really
killed myself on the electronics and so
maybe I've forgotten how much effort
actually went into this because it's
been so long but anyway the idea is that
we start with a piece of ITA coated
glass and idlies I bought on ebay it's
about a little over a millimeter thick
and to make an electroluminescent
display you basically want two
electrodes with a electroluminescent
phosphor and a dielectric between them
and then you just alternate the voltages
on the two electrodes simple in concept
in this case we have a common electrode
like the whole piece of glass that's
coated with I tio is a conductor and the
way we access that electrically is to
just use some conductive epoxy with a
little wire on top and so this wire
becomes the common electrode and then
all the segments are defined by
screen-printing conductive ink onto here
so wherever we have this conductive ink
will define the electrode pattern and
that's what defines the size of the of
the segment there's a couple other
little quirks or little details here the
original disc II had these black screen
printed words on the glass and it also
has these hard to see that little
connector dots now I believe in the
original disc II these little dots on
the display are what they use to
actually contact the common electrode so
instead of doing this conductive epoxy
here with the wire hanging off they
probably had some other method to
connect to the glass itself which was
one continuous electrode through these
little dots I don't know for sure though
I never actually saw the documentation
for that but anyway just to be visually
accurate I wanted to include them
so I screen printed these dots and I
just used silver epoxy it doesn't even
matter what they are it's just for
visual effect and then screen printed
the black wording on here and I used
epoxy black paint which was a really
good choice because later on I had to
take these all apart and build them all
over again and the epoxy is so strong
that I was able to use acetone to strip
off all the chemical or all of the
phosphor layers but it wouldn't actually
strip off the epoxy so I was able to
repaint these over and over again yeah
bug after bug without destroying the
epoxy black paint or that or even the
epoxy silver dots and so I had sort of
multiple chances with each one of these
let's go through the layer stack up so
it's IT o glass black lettering
it's silver epoxy dots then the phosphor
layer is sprayed on to spray pattern
then we spray on the dielectric layer
and then we screen print this black
conductive ink
I looked around for quite a while to
find a screen printable conductive ink
and found some really expensive
solutions one company wanted like $500
for like their trial
quantity of this stuff I'm a silver
conductive ink and instead of doing that
I actually found this company bare
conductive that sells their product on
Amazon and I thought it was you know
it's about a twenty or thirty dollar
product and it's water based which I
thought was a big problem but actually
that turned out to be a benefit later on
and it's as far as I know basically
carbon dust mixed with Elmer's glue or
something very similar to that it's
screen prints beautifully it's very very
thick and viscous super super thick
which makes it easier to screen print
the killer bug with the glass display
the one thing that really held me up
with these is that these came dirty from
the factory so when I first got these
from eBay I was very careful to you know
never touched the surface it came in
like wrapped tissue paper and I was you
know really careful to not get any
fingerprints on there and then I built a
few displays and the failure mode was
that the display wherever I had a
segment it would actually rip the entire
stack up off like all the paint layers
everything will be ripped off the glass
and I thought well that's not fair I
mean that means all of my adhesion is
perfectly good in the stack up but the
adhesion is poor between the stack and
the glass so then I started poking
around at it a little bit more carefully
and noticed that there's some kind of
dirt or contamination on these glass
panels from the factory and so I held
them up side by side and you can see
that there is indeed some sort of a
problem so these two panels were painted
the same way but one was cleaned and one
was direct from the factory so after
making you know four of these to start
with four of these glass panels I
realized I had to go back and strip them
all back down to the glass and clean
them and then respray them and rescreen
print the electrodes so I've probably
done this a total of oh I don't know
eight or ten times in total so I'm
pretty fast at it now
but the reason that I say I was lucky
that this was a water-based screen print
is because it comes off with no effort
whatsoever he just dunk him in water and
it comes right off and then the phosphor
paints also come off there
easily an acetone and leaves the epoxy
stuff so that was kind of a lucky hack
of happenstance next we have to connect
all of these screen printed electrodes
to our electronics somehow and I thought
about this for a long time like how do
you connect 150 segments to your circuit
board and I I settled on this idea of
just using a circuit board itself and
it's okay if the electrode on this part
is not perfectly continuous because that
job is being done by the screen printed
electrode so this is continuous the
electrode here doesn't have to be so if
there's holes for vias that's okay if it
doesn't cover the whole thing that's
okay too
it just has to make some sort of contact
and it has to be within the footprint
defined by the segment here so this this
worked pretty well and my first attempt
was to use what's known as Z tape so
it's like an axially conductive double
stick tape this is actually pretty cool
stuff it does work it's basically double
stick tape with little metal balls
suspended throughout the tape so what
you do is put the tape down and then put
your other object on top when you crush
the two together the metal balls
actually make electrical contact but
they don't short out the segment side to
side because the ball is compressed top
to bottom
it's not like it's conductive throughout
the tape it's literally just conductive
in the Z direction and I had pretty good
luck with it in fact in the opening part
of this video the segment that's a
little bit screwed up it uses tape
that's actually what's inside here it is
three m97 o3 and typically this comes on
little segments like pieces of a roll
that I actually found these four inch
square segments which is pretty
convenient anyway so the problem that I
couldn't get around with using that is
the conductive tape would actually pull
the segments off even after I cleans the
glass the problem got much less its
severe but it was still there it would
still rip little bits of the stack up
off the glass and I you know it was
frustrating because it's kind of like
well if the tape was not you know strong
enough to make I also had a problem
where it wouldn't connect with every
segment and so if you look at that
opening clip again the
the segments at the bottom of the
display are not fully illuminated like
there's some that aren't making
electrical contact so I was having the
problem on both ends of the spectrum the
tape wasn't good enough to make contact
but it was also strong enough that it
was ripping the stack up off the glass
again so I ended up abandoning that and
just going with plain old conductive
epoxy it was a little bit of a like I
didn't even expect this to work very
well but much to my surprise it worked
nearly a hundred percent the first time
out so I just mixed up two part
conductive epoxy and dispensed it on to
these electrode segments and then
squashed it down with the circuit board
and applied a little bit of pressure and
heat and what do you know it looks great
if I were gonna build more of these or
ramping up production in any way what I
would do is make another screen print
mask that is a very smart print of each
of these segments and then screen print
the conductive epoxy on here and then
sandwich the circuit board down on top
of that I'm dispensing it with the hand
the handpiece at hand pneumatic
dispenser is fine for one or two and I
was also concerned that the squeeze out
would basically ruin the definition but
that turned out not to be that big of a
problem the margin of how big or small
of a dollop there could be was was not
that bad okay so we've got our glass
connected to our circuit board here all
the segments are connected up to these
forward two board connectors and we've
got our common electrode here connected
to the glass so let's talk about how to
drive this electrically the driver
circuit is fairly similar to the one
that I used last year for my
electroluminescent display projects
these are HV 507 high-voltage shift
registers so the idea is that you shift
in a pattern of bits and then it just
makes a high voltage output for each one
of those bits that you shift in and
these chips run at about 300 volts I
think the absolute maximum is 325 so if
you shift in 1 1 0 you get 325 325 and 0
volts and you can shift in pretty quick
about six megahertz and there's a latch
so that when you're shifting in the
output lines don't change until you flip
the latch so you get them all to change
at the same time now the thing that
drives this
whole deal is an ATM d21 processor this
is pulled from the adafruit m0 board and
the reason to do that is that the
bootloader is already on here so you can
just connect it via serial and reprogram
it via serial and the only other chip on
here is this 3.3 to 5 volt converter so
in the original circuit I fudged it a
little bit
these HP 507 chips have a 5-volt logic
rail and must be 5 volts not 3.3 and I
just ignored that and the first circuit
that I built and just gave it 3.3 and it
was ever so slightly out of spec it was
almost meeting spec but not quite but it
worked anyway and so I just kept doing
it and then when I built this board I
was just having so many problems that I
put the voltage shifter in there to
eliminate that as one source of
difficulty even though in the end I
don't think it made a difference
the high voltage comes from these photo
flash charged ICS and the board is laid
out for two parallel charge paths but
that was a bad idea I should just use
one so I only populate one set of these
in fact on this board if you're if you
have sharp eyes you can see I actually
pulled that chip off so only one segment
or one high voltage generator is running
not both of them in parallel so let's
talk about why I bring up with such a
terrible beast on this board I had the
usual dumb problems like for example I
forgot to put a capacitor on the reset
line and with your flinging 300 volts
around it would actually reset itself
just due to coupling okay so that's
that's you know your standard dumb bugs
but the real killer the thing that just
absolutely made this thing impossible to
to solve quickly was that it would
destroy itself
so the very first time I did board bring
up I I had it set up where it would
illuminate one segment at a time and
every time I clicked a button on the
computer it moved to the next segment
and so after testing you know about 20
segments I thought oh great this thing's
working perfect and then when I got to
segment 21 I heard a faint click and the
whole thing went dead and then upon
further investigation I realized that
pretty much every chip on the entire
board was blown out two of these were
gone even the MCU was gone I didn't have
a level shifter at the time and so I
thought okay well it pretty much
makes it clear that there's got to be an
arc over somewhere in there and it's
true that when I was running the driver
board without it connected to the
segment board everything was fine and so
I thought well yeah that means there
must be some kind of you know my
conductive screen-printing must be like
really close together at some point it's
arcing over and then the arc causes you
know the whole circuit to blow out and I
spent many many many hours chasing this
around and then I realized that there
was no arc there that definitely was not
the problem to sum it up here's the
problem the way this thing looks to
electrically is like a giant capacitor
that's distributed with different
electrodes so the common electrode is
like one plate of the capacitor and then
each of the segments is sort of like
smaller plates that are connected to the
same big plate like this and then this
big plate is basically one so this is
the common electrode and each one of
these are the segments now if we want to
have a really good electroluminescent
display what we want to do is alternate
the voltage bipolar on these segments so
common electrode of zero volts the
segment is 300 and then we flip them so
the segment is zero and the common is
300 this is great because then the net
voltage across the thing is zero so
there's no polarization effects and we
also get a really bright display because
it's actually going through a delta of
600 volts instead of just 300 okay so
far so good
so let's imagine a scenario where we
only want one segment illuminated say
this top one so all of these other
segments and the common are being driven
in phase with each other so we don't
want these to emit light so this is
going from zero to 300 at the same rate
as all of these but this top segment
that we want to emit light is being
driven out of phase that we get light
emitted from it now what's going to
happen here is all of these other
segments plus the common is going R is
going to gang up against this one so
imagine that each one of these basically
goes to a totem pole driver that's
inside the HP 507 so each one of these
has like a a transistor that goes to 300
volts and a transistor that goes to
ground and the chip is controlling these
transistors to either dump current into
or out of these lines so there's a
hundred and fifty segments connected up
or something and each one of them has a
totem-pole driver connected to a segment
and then for the common electrode I have
eight of them gang together for current
handling capabilities so you have a
hundred and sixty of these totem-pole
drivers on this side of the capacitor
remember all these are being driven in
phase so basically this entire bit is
all being driven at the same time so
essentially a 150 of these totem-pole
drivers against this one guy that has
only one totem-pole driver here so
what's going to happen let's say the
common is at 300 and the segment is at
zero and we're gonna flip it so the
common is going from 300 down to zero
and the segment is going from zero to
300 but the amount of drive strength on
this side of the capacitor is much much
higher a hundred and fifty times higher
so as this thing starts to transition
the voltage on this part of the cap is
going to try to be forced down to
negative 300 volts right because this
cap was charged up to 300 volts and now
we're pulling that 300 volt side down to
zero and it's going to be pulled a lot
faster 150 times faster than this side
of the cap so what ends up happening is
this this point in the circuit
momentarily goes very negative and my
assumption here was that the HP 507 has
protection diodes which it does and it
says they have them in the in the
datasheet and so you know this whole
capacitor is maybe 10 nano ferrous or
something like that so certainly the
protection diode should be able to dump
that current safely but for some reason
it doesn't and so on the scope you can
see what's happening here
we're getting really negative voltages
on this line in this configuration like
about you know negative 50 or 60 volts
even and what was happening is without
the protection diode working eventually
the voltage would get so negative that
it would
some part of the chip and cause a low
resistance path to basically dump
high-voltage into the control lines and
then that would propagate back through
the circuit and just pop every chip down
the line very very frustrating I went
through hundreds of dollars worth of
these HP 507 chips oh my god it's like I
say this is one of the most difficult
board bring ups it is the most difficult
board bring up ever because testing this
until I realized this is what was
happening it's impossible to test right
because you put it together you turn it
on and it goes click and now
everything's dead and even if you have
scope probes on there it's it's not
always easy to catch this in the act
right because if you measure any one of
these other electrodes everything looks
totally fine and if you turn on all the
electrodes at once it's also fine
because then the thing is balanced
pretty well throughout it's only when
you have this electrode imbalance this
basically drives strength imbalance that
you end up with this voltage undershoot
problem obviously the display has to
work with any number of segments
illuminated so how do we solve this we
can't change the drive strength balance
because it's kind of physically set and
if we change how the segments are
illuminated you know we can't you know
change our minds later so what I came up
with is to do this in sort of a
two-phase pattern so in the original
drive pattern the common electrode would
be out of phase with the segment
electrode if we wanted it illuminated
like that and this was causing the
problem so in the common goes low it has
this massive drive strength advantage
and then causes this thing to dip
negative which is blowing out chips and
causing wasting money so the solution I
came up with was to drive the common and
segment electrodes out of phase so in
this case instead of shifting in both at
the same time we always shift the
segment electrode first so if we have a
300 volt potential built up here if we
change the segment electrode first it
can't really cause any of this
undershoot problem because we aren't
traversing across 0 so for example if
common is 300 in a segment at 0 and then
we flip the segment on to 300 volts
there's no way we can get an undershoot
in that circumstance because all this
stuff is staying station
and then when we pull common down this
thing is already charged up to 300 volts
and common is going from 300 down to
zero so there's no way we could
understand zero in that case so we've
sort of moved the problem away by just
doing it in two parts but we still get
the light benefits of traversing a total
of double the supply voltage so if we
kept common at zero the whole time and
just shifted segment on and off the
display would not be nearly as bright by
doing it this way we get the brightness
benefits and it doesn't blow itself up
one last wrinkle with this is the common
electrode itself so I mentioned that I
have eight IO lines ganged together to
make this common electrode for current
handling capabilities but you can tell
there's going to be an imbalance here
again so we have eight on this side and
if all the segments are on then we have
a hundred and fifty on this side and it
will in fact be quite imbalanced again
and we know that the protection diodes
don't work in the HP 507 for some reason
so I added diodes here going you know
whichever which way you know and to make
sure that this this thing can never get
outside this you're at a 300 volt supply
range and it definitely will if you
don't put these diodes here another
thing that I realized that was probably
a problem is you don't want to connect
these lines together directly so if you
have the HP 507 you probably don't want
to just gang a whole bunch of these
together because the resistance is so
low if the drive strength is very
slightly different between them like the
slew rates are very slightly different
these totem-pole drivers aren't
perfectly matched then that means
there's going to be a lot of current
flow and annoyingly it will work for a
long time like an hour or two even and
then it decides to die without any
reason like it'll just be sitting here
running like this and I figure out great
I've got it done now and then an hour or
two later and the thing kills itself so
I added some resistors so that the lines
coming from the HP 507 each go through
their own current limiting resistor then
are ganged together with the diode
protection and then into here so
basically all these things are just to
ensure that the voltages on these lines
never get outside the range of 0 to 300
apply voltage and just for the record
here this one is running it maybe about
75% of its voltage of its maximum
voltage and I've been too chicken to
turn it up because this one's working so
well I can't do it just yet so after
this video I'll try cranking it up a bit
it actually does get a fair bit brighter
than this the firmware is all written in
Arduino and it's mostly just a bunch of
bit shifting there's not in fact there's
no libraries in here at all and there's
a bunch of control variables at the top
that you can play with to change how
this thing operates I would not
recommend playing with the drive pattern
unless you really feel like you know
what you're doing for all these reasons
with unforeseen consequences with drive
strength and undershoot and whatnot it's
very safe to change all the pixel value
settings so in the main loop you can set
pixel values to whatever you want and
that's very safe because that's not
going to hurt anything but if you
changed the actual shift register
control loop which does the actual bit
shifting you probably want to have some
extra chips on hand when you when you
come up with a pulse sequence that
doesn't quite work but it's it's kind of
fun in a way it's a real puzzle and you
know people solve jigsaw puzzles because
it's a way to pass the time and you
learn something and feel good about it
so I'm happy with how this project
turned out I really do like how this
looks and it's running fine now and I
should also add that we can send data to
it over the serial link so the whole
point of making this display is that you
can integrate it with another piece of
the Apollo guidance computer and so we
can connect up with USB and send it
serial data okay see you next time bye
